title: Foundations in Public Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken MEDF1021, UGEC1920 or UGEC2930.
description: (UGEC1920 is double-coded with PHPC1001.) This course will introduce undergraduate students to the discipline of public health and its basic academic framework, concept and methodology. The objective of the course is to provide a broad intellectual perspective of public health and presents both local and global public health challenges that are facing our society in the 21st century. The various academic disciplines within the domains of public health that include environmental health sciences, health policy and management, social and behavioral sciences and basic science will be introduced and discussed. The impact of these public health problems in relation to our society and our everyday lives will be emphasized. An analytic public health problem solving framework will be used to enable students to appreciate and learn the problem solving methodology in evaluating and appraising various public health problems.
outcome: By the end of this course, the students should be able to: -Examine the key domains of public health -Recognize the important public health issues in the 21st century -Recognize the multidisciplinary nature of public health and determine major public health issues in both local and international settings and their relevance to our society and daily life  -Appraise the inter-related and complex nature of the concept of health, taking into account the important influences from our environment, social and health system and services, values of our society, our culture and biological predisposition -Use critical and analytical thinking in analyzing public health problems  -Understand the socio-economic, cultural, political and ethical issues related to public health
syllabus: 1. Overview, Foundation Concepts and History of Public Health   2. The Origins and Achievements of Public Health   3. title: Principles of Infectious Diseases
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC1004.
description: This course provides an introduction to the causation, epidemiology and prevention and control of infectious diseases in a public health context. Essential microbiology and immunology would be included. Concepts of the relationship among agent, host and environment will be covered. Impacts of infectious diseases on society will be discussed. Illustrations will be given using both historical events and topical issues.
outcome: By the end of this course, student should be able to:  1. acquire basic concepts and knowledge in microbiology, pathogenesis, immunity against infectious diseases in human  2. appreciate the clinical presentations and principles of management of infectious diseases  3. understand the principles and public health strategies for control and prevention of infections  4. understand the interactions between infectious diseases, society and the environment
syllabus: 1. Introduction to infectious diseases and microbiology 2. 1. Transmission of infections  2. Introduction to infectious disease epidemiology  3. Strategies for preventing infections in public health  3. Host response to infection and use of vaccines 4. Principles of infectious disease management and outbreak control 5. 1. Infection control in healthcare settings  2. Infections and society

description: This course provides a substantive overview of the relationship between major lifestyle behaviors and health outcomes. title: Environment and Work
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken CHPR2001
description: This public health oriented course addresses how the environmental and occupational (work-related) factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. Whereas environmental science tends to address how human beings affect the environment, this course focuses on how the environment affects human health. Topics include an introduction to the toxicology and environmental epidemiology methods in assessing the impact of environmental exposures on human health; how the physical, chemical or biological agents in the air, water, soil and food affect human health; the evaluation and control of common hazards in the work place; and the impacts of global environmental changes on health.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1.Discuss the history and definition of environmental health and occupational health 2.Describe epidemiology, toxicology and risk analysis methods to evaluate the impact of environmental exposures on human health 3.Define the major sources and types of hazards in the environment and workplaces4.Discuss the direct and indirect human health effects of major environmental and occupational agents5.Discuss the general principles of environmental pollution mitigation and occupational hazard control6.Discuss local, regional and international regulatory programs, guidelines and authorities on environmental and occupational health
syllabus: 1. Introduction2. Exposure, dose and risk analysis3. Fundamentals of environmental epidemiology4. Environmental hazard and health impact5. Natural environment and health6. Work and health7. Occupational disease and injury; Occupational legislation8. Environmental health problems in Hong Kong9. Environmental health for all: local and global perspective10. The atmosphere and air pollution11. Water and food safety12. Solid and hazardous waste

Friis.Sudbury, Mass. : Jones and Bartlett, c2007. 3.Occupational Health Practice. H.A. Waldron, Butterworths. (4th edition)

title: Health Care System & Policy
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Healthcare systems are complex and multidisciplinary in nature. They need to meet population needs and may include a network of services such as prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and health maintenance provided to individuals of all ages and with a range of needs. Policy plays an important role in maximizing the function of health care systems. This course is an introductory course on basic definitions and functions of health care systems. Using case studies and discussions, students will be able to develop understanding of policy and practice in health care. This course also provides a brief overview of how health economics and financing, hospital organization and management, and different parties are involved in healthcare systems.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: • Understand how health and social care are interrelated and delivered • Understand the basic concepts and functions of health and care systems for primary, secondary and tertiary care • Gain a brief overview of different healthcare systems from local and global perspectives • Identify the basic elements of health policy and its impact on health care systems • Gain a brief overview of the role health economics and financing plays in the healthcare system • Gain a brief understanding of hospital organization and management, and different parties involvement in healthcare system
syllabus: 1. What is health care system & its components & function?2. Healthcare Delivery (I)3. Healthcare Delivery (II)4. Resources Required in Healthcare5. Financing for healthcare6. Health Policy I: Definition & Perspective7. Health Policy II: Case Discussion8. Field Visits

title: Global Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisite:PHPC1001 or MEDF1021 or UGEC1920 or UGEC2930
description: This course will introduce how public health principles may be applied to understand and examine health issues and initiatives in global settings.Students will build up a knowledge base in global public health issues and will identify global health problems and devise possible solutions to these problems. Public health issues in specific countries such as Sri Lanka, Nigeria, India, China, Bhutan, Indonesia, USA, United Kingdom etc. will be identified and students will work in teams, develop critical thinking skills and expand their knowledge base in public health and provide possible solutions of global health issues. They will communicate their findings to each other and to the whole class in presentations. The contexts from which these public health issues arise in these countries would be compared and contrasted to the contexts of Hong Kong. The course would provide opportunities for development of relevant attributes by the use of issue-based teaching approaches e.g. students will be engaged in learning tasks which require them to analyse in depth of a global health issue of a specified country, appreciate the complex nature of dynamics which shape global health issues and agenda, understand various perspectives of the stakeholders (nations, governments, non-government body, civil society etc) and demonstrate the values of global citizenship, and come up with possible solutions which include defining goals, formulation of strategies/action plans, gathering and identification of resources needs and the skills to communicate with stakeholders.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Be equipped with the knowledge base and skills to identify and analyse global health issues  2. Be aware of the contextual factors which come into play in global health issues and develop relevant attributes and skills to consider possible solutions 3. Demonstrate the role and responsibility of global citizenships and how individual might be related to the protection of global health and public health 4. Identify key stakeholders in global health and its underlying decision making dynamics, and able to engage with them 5. Understand current trends and thematic issues in global health and arouse international awareness 6. Examine and discuss key health priorities such as SDGs, Sendai Framework, Urban Agenda and Paris agreements in a global environment  7. Have divergent and convergent thinking to formulate solutions to address the global health challenges
syllabus: 1) Introduction to Global Health & Basic Demography 2) Global Development & Health: Sustainable Development Goals 3) Health in War, Disasters and Emergencies  4) Global Environmental Health: Climate Change and Health  5) Global Nutrition and Food Security  6) Global Health Priorities: Trade agreements, Globalization & Ethics  7) Global Patterns of Non-communicable Diseases  8) Global Trend of Mental Health  9) Global Infectious Diseases  10) Interactive Mega-Exercise  11) Global policy and governance  12) Urbanisation & Rural Health  13) Health of Special Populations

title: Biostatistics
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken -COMM3110, DSME2010,2020,2011,2021, ECON2121, GRMD2102, PHPC1015, PSYC2010, SEEM2430, SPED2600, STAT2101,2102,2001 or 2006.
description: This course will introduce the basic biostatistics concepts and their applications in health data analysis. Emphasis will be placed on conceptual understanding of statistical approaches to medical data rather than on theory and equations. Students will learn the importance of the correct use of statistical methods in addressing questions of public health importance. The course will enable students to develop the statistical literacy necessary to interpret the vast amounts of information they must process for decision making. The biostatistics concepts will be taught together with a user-friendly software SPSS for performing basic statistical analyses.Grade descriptorsA Outstanding performance on all learning outcomes.A- Generally outstanding performance on all (or almost all) learning outcomes.B Substantial performance on all learning outcomes, OR high performance on some learning outcomes which compensates for less satisfactory performance on others, resulting in overall substantial performance.C Satisfactory performance on the majority of learning outcomes, possibly with a few weaknesses.D Barely satisfactory performance on a number of learning outcomesF Unsatisfactory performance on a number of learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements.
outcome: By the end of this course, student should be able to:  1. have an understanding of the fundamental concepts of probability and basic statistics. 2. apply this knowledge towards improved understanding of reports on research findings and better decision making.
syllabus: 1.Introduction to biostatistics 2.Introduction to descriptive statistics: Levels of measurement, measuring central tendency and variability, frequency tables. 3.Probability;  4.Probability distributions:Normal, binomial, Poisson 5.Sampling distributions 6.Estimation and confidence intervals 7.Hypothesis testing: t-tests 8.Hypothesis testing: Categorical data 9.Nonparametric tests 10.Correlation and simple linear regression 11.Multiple linear regression I 12.Multiple linear regression II 13.Practical data analysis/ Interpretation of statistical results
recommended_readings: 1. Statistics Notes in the British Medical Journal, free downloads at: http://www-users.york.ac.uk/~mb55/pubs/pbstnote.htm

title: Epidemiology
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC1014.
description: This course aims to provide a basic understanding of the fundamental principles of epidemiological methods and their applicability to the field of health research. Students will grasp the basic skills needed to critically interpret scientific studies and to conduct simple epidemiological studies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Become familiar with the commonly used study designs used in epidemiological research and their shortcomings and advantages. 2. Understand the most important methodological issues surrounding epidemiological studies such as bias and confounding.  3. Be familiar with the commonly used data collection methods 4. Know how to apply their knowledge to critically appraising scientific studies. 5. Be able to write a simple epidemiological protocol similar to those used in professional grant submissions

Effect modification, bias, and causal inference in epidemiology 11. Principles of Screening 12. Brief overview of Systematic Reviews

title: Infectious Diseases of Public Health Importance

description: The course provides an overview of the epidemiology of infectious diseases of global and local public health concern. Sexually transmitted infections, waterborne and foodborne infections, vector borne infections, tropical infections, infections transmitted through air, droplets, direct contact or blood are included. academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This course is inspiring and provide you a valuable insight through tutorial, simulation, sharing and experience learning in real community setting. Upon different learning activities, students will be able to develop understanding on the challenges of older generation with chronic disease and their wisdom; and obtain basic knowledge and framework of self-care management with views from different stakeholders involving in the healthcare system. This course provides a unique opportunity to apply knowledge and skill learnt from the course to enhance elderly’ health and experience healthcare service delivery with elderly.

title: Health Care System Field Studies
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This study tour is to give a great learning experience of how the health system works in other jurisdictions. With the study tour, students can gain first-hand experiences and grasp certain knowledge about the health system, its structure, governance, financing and service delivery provision in specific jurisdiction which may varies in each year depending on the site arrangement of corresponding study tour. Students will identify the strengths of the system, how it produces good outcome and what challenges it tackles in order to achieve the good health and high quality of healthcare in population. The study tour also ties policy with health system in a broader context. Students are required to select a study topic of interest, for example, healthcare financing and universal coverage, long term care, quality of healthcare delivery, and impact of policy in population health and then to review literature, to collect information from the places visited and seminar, and to deliver a presentation in the class.This course will be held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. Students are responsible for all travel expenses in the study tour, including air fares, accommodation, food, transportation and travel insurance.The objectives of the course are three-fold: (1) to offer students a field-based education in their undergraduate programs for the extension of classroom learning through direct observation, sharing and experience;(2) to deepen students’ understanding on health system in a broader context including its structure, governance, financing and service delivery provision; and (3) to provide students a comprehensive view on local and regional public health issues in health system.

title: Public Health Ethics and Law
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHPC1001 or UGEC1920 or MEDF1021 or UGEC2930.
description: This course will introduce students to the basic concepts of ethics and law and explore their relevance to professional and clinical public health practices. It will introduce students to the role of ethics and law in promoting and protecting public health. Case studies will be used to highlight contemporary ethical and legal issues in public health in Hong Kong.
outcome: 1. Understand basic ethical concepts and applications  2. Discuss contemporary ethical dilemmas in public health and health care scenarios 3. Understand basic legal terminology and sources of law in Hong Kong 4. Understand Hong Kong’s public health legislation  5. Understand the importance of ethics and law in protecting public health  6. Identify and analyze different approaches to decision-making in relation to public health dilemmas and the relevant ethics considerations  7. Demonstrate an understanding of public health as a public good in Hong Kong

title: Evidence Based Public Health and Healthcare
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: For students of new curriculum only.;Not for students who have taken PHPC2014.;Pre-requisites: PHPC2015 & PHPC2017.
description: Building on students’ skills in epidemiology and biostatistics, this module will introduce advanced concepts and skills in evidence-based public health and healthcare. Students will acquire the skills in turning public health and healthcare queries into focused questions on effectiveness, diagnostic and screening performances and cost-effectiveness. Students will be equipped with skills to critically appraise the validity and generalizability of research findings, to synthesize evidence and to translate knowledge into action.
outcome: By the end of this course, student should be able to: Master advanced skills in practicing evidence based public health and healthcare, including the formulation of focused clinical questions, critique on the validity and generalizability of evidence, synthesis of evidence, and translating knowledge into action.

title: Environment and Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHPC2009 or CHPR2001
description: This course addresses how environmental factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. It examines the environmental health issues and recent development in industrialized and developing countries. It also covers risk analysis and communication, environmental health policy, and emerging environmental health problems.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Discuss the scope of environmental health as a field of research and practice  2. Discuss the exposure assessment, epidemiology and toxicology methods to assess the risk of environmental exposures on human health 3. Discuss the human health effects of various environmental hazards  4. Describe the basic principles and methods of environmental monitoring 5. Discuss health outcomes linked to local environmental changes
syllabus: 1. A preview of environmental health 2. Toxicology basics 3. Environmental monitoring 4. Exposure Assessment 5. Indoor air pollution and health 6. Risk analysis and communication 7. Environmental health policy 8. Environmental epidemiology methods 9. Air pollution epidemiology 10. Lab -- Health outcome measurement 11. Lab -- water pollution measurement 12. Lab -- air pollution measurement 13. Site visit – sewage treatment plant
required_readings: 1. Understanding Environmental Health: How We Live in the World. Nancy Irwin Maxwell, Jones & Bartlett Publishers, latest edition.  2. Environmental Health: From Global to Local. Howard Frumkin, Jossey-Bass; latest edition.

title: Work and Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This course adopts a systematic approach to the study of occupational health and hygiene, and addresses both the effects of work on health and the effects of health on work. It covers the scopes and principles of occupational health and hygiene, toxicological assessment and occupational exposure limits, principles of ergonomics, occupational diseases and sharp injuries, occupational epidemiology and exposure assessment, common cancers in Hong Kong and the related occupation, as well as public health issues in occupational health.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Be able to describe the scopes and principles of occupational health and hygiene; 2. Understand common occupational hazards and the relation between work and health;  3. Know basic skills of conducting an occupational health hazards evaluation; 4. Be conversant with the basic techniques in assessing occupational exposures, controlling occupational hazards, and occupational epidemiology; 5. Be articulate in major occupational health and safety challenges as well as environmental impacts on workers health;
syllabus: 1. An overview of occupational health and hygiene 2. Chemical and biological health hazards in the workplace 3. Physical health hazards in the workplace 4. Principles of ergonomics and prevention 5. Toxicological assessment and occupational exposure limits 6. Hazard evaluation and instrumentation 7. Control of hazards and safety issues 8. Health hazards evaluation – workplace site visit 9. Occupational diseases and sharp injuries 10. Occupational epidemiology in practice 11. Common cancers and the related occupation and environment 12. Workplace wellness
required_readings: 1. Jeremy Stranks. Occupational Health and Hygiene. Pitman Publishing.2. Waldron HA and Edling C. Occupational Health Practice. Butterworth-Heinemann; fourth edition.3. Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) [http://osha.gov/]4. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) [http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/].

title: Environmental Health Field Studies
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisite: CHPR2001 or PHPC2009 or PHPC3016
description: This field study course is supplementary to the three classroom-based courses CHPR2001, PHPC2009 and PHPC3016 on the environmental factors in public health. Students can gain first-hand experiences and grasp certain practical skills by conducting the field studies in Hong Kong, China and other areas. Environmental health is about how the environmental factors may adversely impact the public health and what we can do to prevent or minimize these impacts. By the scale, the hazards can be local (e.g., industrial and household pollution, traffic exhaust), regional (e.g., deteriorating regional air quality), or global (e.g., climate change); by the relationship to social development, the hazards can be traditional (e.g., household hygiene) or modern (e.g., new chemicals). Without field studies, the students may have difficulties in understand the broad scopes of environmental health practice. This course is to fill in this gap by conducting local and regional field studies and equipping the students with practical skills (e.g., air sampling techniques) in environmental monitoring, risk assessment and management. Students are first required to select a study topic of interest, for example air pollution and respiratory diseases, water pollution and metal industry, and social development and sustainability, and then to review literature, to collect information from the places visited, and to write up a final report.This course will be held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. Students are responsible for all travel expenses in the field study, including transportation, food, accommodation, and travel insurance.The objectives of the course are three-fold: (1) to offer students a field-based education early in their undergraduate programs for the extension of classroom learning through direct observation and experience; (2) to deepen students’ understanding on relationships between environment and health, with emphasis on pollution, social development, and sustainability; and (3) to provide students a comprehensive view on local and regional public health issues.

title: Economics and Financing in Healthcare Systems
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: (UGEC3927 is double-coded with PHPC3024.) Should health care be privatized? Why is health insurance bad to your health? Who should pay the enormous cost of rare disease care? Finally, should I getting married or stay as single? All these questions are related to health economics (yes, even the last one). The course will introduce the key features in health economics analysis, such as demand and supply, equity vs efficiency, and cost-effectives analysis, a tool to prioritise health programs to efficiently maximise resources allocation. The course will also introduce healthcare financing and its impact on health care system. Students will be able to identify different models of healthcare financing around the world.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Understand basic concepts of economics and its application in different healthcare settings  2. Identify economic issues and use economic rationale to support argument in a healthcare policy debate 3. Apply economics to improve the equity and efficiency in the health sector 4. Explain how health care in Hong Kong and elsewhere is financed 5. Evaluate health programs and policies from an economic perspective

title: Health Promotion in Practice - Social Marketing
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisites: (PHPC1016 or PHPC2016) and (PHPC1022 or PHPC2008).
description: This course aims to equip students with practical skills to apply health promotion concepts and methodology to resolve real-life public health problems. The course will give a deep examination of commonly used behavioural health models and teach practical skills in designing, implementing and evaluating behavioural intervention programmes. It covers areas such as formative research, scoping, implementation process, frameworks of health promotion, health communication skills, methods of designing and disseminating health messages, use of appropriate health settings and strategies for community involvement. Social marketing will be used as the main framework, integrating with general health promotion methods such as scoping, setting, behavioural change techniques, health communication and evaluation methods. The course will also provide hands-on training on the complete process of health promotion programme development.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: 1. Apply health promotion concepts, theories and methods to practice. 2. Understand principles and applications of social marketing for health improvement. 3. Apply skills commonly used in health promotion such as needs assessment, engagement of stakeholders, program planning, implementation, dissemination and marketing, and evaluation.

description: Qualitative research in public health has become more important and is rapidly expanding. title: Practical Data Collection, Management and Analysis
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisites: (PHPC1014 or PHPC2017) and (PHPC1015 or PHPC2015)
description: This course will provide practical hands-on training to students in data collection, management and analysis. Students will learn about questionnaire design, sample size calculation, data collection methods, data entry, data cleaning, data confidentiality, data analysis and presentation of results from quantitative public health studies. The course will emphasize the quantitative and computing skills necessary for students to carry out research projects. A popular and user-friendly statistical software, SPSS, will be used.

title: Applied Economics Evaluation in Health Care
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisites: PHPC2015 & PHPC3024
description: Economic evaluation is a comparative science in which health interventions are compared in terms of both their costs and their effectiveness. In this course we will have a brief review of the basic principles, potential roles and limitations of economic evaluation. The course covers use of decision trees and state transition models, involving practical sessions in which participants develop, populate, and analyse cost-effectiveness models, using general software like Excel and more advance open access software like R. On completion of the course, students will have the necessary knowledge and materials to undertake a basic health economic evaluation; to explore methods for more complex evaluations; and to critically review the conduct and validity of presented or published evaluations.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:•    Differentiate types of economic evaluations and modelling techniques to address policy questions in health care •    Describe and discuss issues on measuring and valuing resource allocation in health care•    Plan, undertake and conduct economic evaluation of an actual health intervention•    Present output from economic evaluations, interpret its results, and discuss how results should be applied in priority setting
syllabus: 1.    Introduction to economic evaluation2.    Utility measures: QALY and DALY3.    Cost-effectiveness analysis4.    Decision tree analysis5.    Economic evaluation modelling using Excel: Introduction, build a decision tree model6.    Economic evaluation modelling using Excel: Incorporate uncertainty in model inputs in an economic model7.    Economic evaluation modelling using Excel: Practical assessment8.    Economic evaluation modelling using R: Introduction9.    Economic evaluation modelling using R: Build a decision tree model10.    Economic evaluation modelling using R: Incorporate uncertainty in model inputs in an economic model 11.    Economic evaluation modelling using R: Sensitivity Analysis12.    Economic evaluation modelling using R: Practical assessment

title: Health Care Quality
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Pre-requisite: PHPC1001 or 2010
description: This course will use the philosophy of health care quality in patient-centered care & safety to examine the roles of healthcare professions, patients and carers in the healthcare system; concept of care; and drivers for healthcare quality. Case scenario will be used to foster better understanding of the course content.

title: Healthcare Organisation and Management
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This is an introductory course on the management, organizational structure and behavior, and leadership of health care institutions. This course will use lectures, case studies, and team-based learning to teach students about basic theories, skills, and concepts about managing people and situations unique to health care settings. In addition to introducing students to how health care organizations work on a business level, this course also emphasizes on developing their leadership skills, working in a team, and communication skills that are necessary for health care managers.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to: 1. Gain a basic understanding of healthcare management 2. Identify the roles of human resources management, operational and financial management, quality improvement and information management in health care settings. 3. Apply organizational behavior and structure theories towards understanding local and international healthcare organizations 4. Understand the concept of strategic management and leadership principles 5. Further one's professional development in health care settings by developing leadership and communication skills 6. Effectively solve problems and make decisions for scenarios in health care settings
syllabus: 1. Introduction to healthcare organization (HCO) and management2. Risk Assessment and Management and Communication3. Conflict management and negotiation & Strategy4. Managers and managerial decision making in HCO5. Team building and creating a high-performance workplace6. Program management and project management7. Health care marketing8. Motivating people in an organization9. Change management and Leadership  10. Application of management theory in Government Services

title: Gender and Age-Related Healthcare
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Prerequisite:PHPC1001 or MEDF1021 or UGEC1920 or UGEC2930.
description: This course examines the interaction between gender and health. The course will utilize a life course framework to discuss public health issues across the life span including women of childbearing age, infants, children, adolescents, working adults and elderly. Broad topics will include gender roles, gender analysis, gender inequalities in health, empowerment, teen health, HIV, LGBT issues, reproductive health, sex workers, domestic workers and elderly abuse.

title: Public Health Practicum
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Students will be assigned to one of the collaborating public health service providers, including (but not limited to) government departments, non-governmental organizations and the private sectors, based on their declared preference. Prior to the engagement of practicum, each student must discuss his or her potential role and responsibilities with the site supervisor. All fieldwork can only be initiated after the prior approval of the course coordinator and site supervisor. Students are required to complete a minimum of 100 hours of field work under the supervision of site supervisor.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:1. Apply academic theories and acquired skills to community-based programme or service or evaluation in a real-life setting2. Understand the vision, missions, values, and the populations served by the designated organization3. Communicate public health concepts clearly in verbal and written forms and familiarize with multi-disciplinary public health practice4. Expand their networks with key stakeholders of public health
syllabus: 1. Practicum plan presentation 2. Fieldwork practicum in a designated organization (at least 100 hours) 3. Poster presentation
required_readings: Not applicable
